thread.title: Hammond defends Xi’s UK welcome

title: Hammond defends Xi’s UK welcome
text:
Xi Jinping ‘red carpet’ welcome defended by UK foreign secretary George Parker and Conor Sullivan ©Reuters China's President Xi Jinping and Britain's Prince Philip review an honour guard during his official welcoming ceremony in London 
Britain is embarking on its wooing of China’s Xi Jinping with “eyes wide open”, according to Philip Hammond, foreign secretary, as the Chinese president began a four-day state visit. 
Mr Xi addressed both Houses of Parliament and will attend a state banquet at Buckingham Palace as David Cameron’s government seeks to cement Britain’s claim to be China’s number one partner in the west. More UK migrant benefits key to EU talks 
The Chinese president said Britain and China were becoming “increasingly interdependent” parts of a “community of shared interests”. 
Speaking in Mandarin, Mr Xi said he believed his four-day state visit would help lift the friendly relationship between the two countries to “a new height”. 
The address, in Parliament’s Royal Gallery, is a high point of the first state visit by a Chinese leader for 10 years. 
Mr Xi, who arrived in the UK on Monday evening, said: “Although my visit has just started, I am already deeply impressed by the vitality of China-UK relations and the profound friendship between our peoples. 
“This gives me good reason to believe that my visit will lift the friendly ties between our two countries to a new height.” 
Responding to some international criticism that Britain was not critical enough of an authoritarian regime, Mr Hammond said: “We don’t think we are being naive. We go into all relationships with our eyes wide open.” 
He told the BBC: “We want to be the most open economy in Europe to Chinese investment. We want to trade with China to ensure British jobs and prosperity.” In depth 
Xi Jinping: UK state visit 
The Chinese president is set to address parliament, dine at Buckingham Palace and ride in a royal carriage as London rolls out the reddest of red carpets for the Communist party leader 
Mr Hammond said Britain was one of the few western economies which had opened large-scale infrastructure projects — including nuclear power — to foreign investment and that China wanted “some of that action”. 
He said it would be “dangerous” to invite China to invest in Britain for political reasons and said that any contracts signed during Mr Xi’s visit would be rooted in commercial advantage on both sides. 
On Tuesday morning, Mr Xi was driven down the Mall with the Queen in a gilded carriage, cheered on by throngs of Chinese wearing matching T-shirts bussed in from across the UK. Protesters were limited to one small section on one side of the avenue and police could be seen asking people with Tibetan flags to move to this area. Lea Reed, 32 from Cambridge, said she had come up to London with her Chinese friend on one of “tons” of buses laid on for the occasion. She was wearing a “I love China” T-shirt with the two countries’ flags that she said was handed out onboard.
